## [Background]{.title-deco .bg-r}

::: sub
An Overview of Existing Causal Inference Methodology
:::

::: {.columns style="font-size:30px;top:0%;"}
::: {.column width="70%"}
::: {.infobox .li-m}
-   Most methods utilize **conterfactual (potential outcomes)** framework

-   We **manipulate the exposure** for the [same observations]{.red} and then compare outcomes under different exposures

-   Mostly, binary exposures are used \[what if everyone [exposed]{.red} Vs what if everyone [not exposed]{.green}\]

-   Known as **static interventions**

::: fragment
![](img/cf1.png){.absolute bottom="0%" left="10%" width="230"}
:::
:::
:::

::: {.column width="29%"}
::: {.infobox .bg-r .fragment}
[Some Limitations]{.red .lrb-r}

1.  Positivity violations

2.  Unrealistic interventions

3.  Cannot depend on the observed exposure

4.  Policy implications of conterfactual extremes ü§î

5.  Forced to dichotomise the exposure
:::
:::
:::

## [Background]{.title-deco .bg-b} {.li-m}

::: sub
What are Modified Treatment Policies
:::

::: f-22
-   A collection of nonparametric alternatives for defining and yielding effects from interesting causal inference questions.

-   Capable of estimating meaningful interventions with practical relevance such as reducing or increasing the exposure by a given amount.

-   See the paper by Iv√°n D√≠az and colleagues titled *"Nonparametric Causal Effects Based on Longitudinal Modified Treatment Policies"* for further details (R package `lmtp` provides software implementation of the methods).

-   `lmtp` software allows the user to handle:

    -   Cross-sectional or longitudinal exposures

    -   Binary, categorical, or continuous exposures

    -   Exposures that are dependent on time

    -   Time-dependent covariates

    -   Multiple exposures

    -   Binary, continuous, or time-to-event outcomes

    -   Informative loss to follow-up/censoring

    -   Competing risks

    -   Survey weights
:::

## [Methods]{.title-deco .bg-g}

::: sub
Data & the flow of participants
:::

::: panel-tabset
### ***Data & Participants***

::: f-30
-   Data: From the Japan Gerontological Evaluation Study (JAGES)

-   JAGES is an on-going nationwide cohort study for functionally independent older adults in Japan aged 65 years or over

-   Data from the 2010 survey (baseline) and two subsequent follow-up surveys (2013 and 2016) were used.

-   A total of 52,053 individuals participated in the baseline survey

-   24,872 individuals responded to all three waves (4,611 died, 8,099 became ineligible, and 14,471 were lost to follow-up)

-   We included all (52,053) baseline participants with their follow-up state to obtain estimates accounted for censoring

-   Missing data (other than due to censoring) was imputed using multiple imputation
:::

### ***Flow chart***

![](img/flow.png){fig-align="center" width="428"}
:::

## [Methods]{.title-deco .bg-r}

::: sub
Study variables
:::

::: panel-tabset
### Outcome {.f-30 .li-m}

-   Social participation in 2016

-   Participation in any of the activities;

    -   hobby groups
    -   sports clubs
    -   senior citizens clubs
    -   residence groups
    -   or volunteer groups

-   Participation in any of these activities once a month or more frequently (vs.¬†less frequently or never) was defined as indicative of social participation ([1]{.red}=participation, [0]{.red}=non-participation)

### Exposure {.li-m}

-   The number of remaining natural teeth in 2010 and 2013 was used as a [time-varying exposure]{.red}

-   Self-reported number of teeth was recorded in four categories (i.e., \>=20 teeth/ 10-19 teeth/ 1-9 teeth/ no teeth)

### Covariates {.f-30 .li-m}

-   Time-varying nature of covariates were taken into account

-   Time-invariant covariates were;

    -   age (range 65--99 years)
    -   sex (male/female)
    -   social participation in 2010 (outcome at the baseline)

-   Time-varying covariates were;

    -   Annual household income
    -   Self-rated health (very good/ good/ fair/ poor)
    -   Denture use (yes/ no)
    -   Marital status (married/ single, widowed or divorced)

### Hypothesized associations

![](img/dag.png){fig-align="center" width="790"}
:::

## [Methods]{.title-deco .bg-g}

::: sub
Statistical analysis- main steps
:::

::: {.f-25 .nonincremental style="padding-top:20%;"}
[Step 1:]{.green} Defined the causal effect using MTP framework by [__shifting the observed exposure__]{.red} to different hypothetical scenarios


[Step 2:]{.green} Estimate the population level outcome (mean outcome) under different scenarios specified in the step

::: {.bg-b}
>   [Targeted minimum loss-based estimation (TMLE)]{.red} with weighted combination data adaptive regressions (machine learning algorithms) were used to estimate outcomes.

:::

[Step 3:]{.green} [Contrast the outcome estimates]{.red} of hypothetical interventions against the outcome estimate under observed exposure level to calculate odds ratios.
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

## [Methods]{.title-deco .bg-r}

::: sub
Step 2- Estimating outcome under shifted exposures
:::

::: {.absolute .bg-r .infobox .nonincremental .f-20 style="top:30%;width:35%;left:-6%;"}
üéØ Doubly-robust TMLE was used to estimate the expected outcome under;

-   Observed exposure
-   Scenario 1 (\>=20 teeth -\> 10-19 teeth)
-   Scenario 2 (\>=20 teeth & 10-19 teeth -\> 1-9 teeth)
-   Scenario 3 (all edentulous - conterfactual extreme)
-   Scenario 4 (edentulous -\> 1-9 teeth)
-   Scenario 5 (edentulous & 1-9 teeth -\> 10-19 teeth)
:::

::: {.absolute .fragment right="3%" top="12%" width="700px" height="auto"}
![](img/tmle1.png)
:::

:::
